levels.name: Beginner
levels.description: Little to no previous time on sailboats (0–10–15 days total)
levels.infoText:
Little to no previous time on sailboats (0–10–15 days total)

May have done a short introductory sail or a "try sailing" day

Understands very basic concepts (what a tiller/helm is, wind direction, points of sail) but cannot yet apply them independently

Can be a helpful crew member under close supervision (grinding winches, tailing sheets, basic safety awareness)

Cannot skipper even the smallest sailboat independently
levels.typicalEquivalents: RYA Competent Crew start / ASA 101 start / "Green beginner"
levels.note: This level is about safety orientation, terminology, and getting comfortable on the water.

levels.name: Competent Crew
levels.description: Roughly 10–50 days on the water (mix of crew and helm time)
levels.infoText:
Roughly 10–50 days on the water (mix of crew and helm time)

Can actively crew on most points of sail, handle basic maneuvers (tacking, gybing, reefing), assist with mooring/docking, understand basic rules of the road

Has skippered small boats (dinghies or daysailers <30 ft) in light to moderate conditions in familiar, protected waters during daylight

Can take the helm for short periods under supervision on larger cruising boats
levels.typicalEquivalents: RYA Day Skipper practical + some miles / ASA 104 Basic Coastal Cruising / NauticEd Skipper Level I–II / International Bareboat Skipper (entry level)
levels.note: This is the "I can safely take friends out for a weekend sail in good weather" level.

levels.name: Coastal Skipper
levels.description: 50–150+ days on the water, with at least half as skipper/master of the vessel
levels.infoText:
50–150+ days on the water, with at least half as skipper/master of the vessel

Comfortable skippering 30–45 ft cruising yachts as bareboat charter captain

Can plan and execute coastal passages (day & night), handle marina berthing in crosswinds/current, reef early, manage heavy weather tactics in moderate to fresh conditions (up to ~25–30 knots)

Good knowledge of navigation (electronic + traditional), weather interpretation, pilotage, and emergency procedures
levels.typicalEquivalents: RYA Coastal Skipper / Yachtmaster Coastal / IYT Bareboat Skipper with experience / NauticEd Bareboat Charter Master Level III–IV / Most charter companies' "Level 2–3 Qualified Skipper" rating
levels.note: This is the most common level for confident recreational bareboat chartering in the Mediterranean, Caribbean, etc.

levels.name: Offshore Skipper
levels.description: 150–500+ days on the water (very often several hundred), with the majority as skipper
levels.infoText:
150–500+ days on the water (very often several hundred), with the majority as skipper

Extensive experience skippering sailboats in challenging conditions — strong winds (30+ knots), large seas, heavy weather, long offshore passages (multi-day/night), ocean crossings

Very strong all-round seamanship: advanced boat handling (including under storm sails or bare poles), heavy weather tactics, jury rigging, man-overboard in rough conditions, long-distance navigation & routing, crew management in stressful situations

Has likely completed long offshore passages (e.g., Atlantic crossing, multi-week voyages)
levels.typicalEquivalents: RYA Yachtmaster Offshore / Ocean / IYT Yachtmaster Offshore / NauticEd Captain rank + Level V / Charter company "Expert Level" rating with proven offshore resume
levels.note: This level represents the serious, years-of-experience skippers who can confidently take a boat almost anywhere, in almost any conditions, while keeping safety margins high. Many charter companies and sailing communities use similar 3–5 tier systems, but this 4-level breakdown nicely matches the progression from "never sailed" → "can take friends out" → "confident charter skipper" → "seasoned offshore sailor".
